articles.headline: New Hurdle in Investors’ Class Actions
articles.snippet: A Supreme Court decision will let corporate defendants defeat some securities fraud claims at the outset, but it didn’t go as far as some business groups hoped.
articles.abstract: A Supreme Court decision will let corporate defendants defeat some securities fraud claims at the outset, but it didn’t go as far as some business groups hoped.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday made it harder for investors to band together to pursue claims that they were misled when they bought or sold securities. But the justices did not accept a broader challenge, one that could have put an end to most class actions for securities fraud.

articles.headline: Generic Versions of Toprol XL, a Heart Drug, Are Recalled
articles.snippet: Recalls by two large Indian manufacturers, Wockhardt and Dr. Reddy’s Laboratories, are the latest in a string of recent problems involving generic drugs.
articles.abstract: Recalls by two large Indian manufacturers, Wockhardt and Dr. Reddy’s Laboratories, are the latest in a string of recent problems involving generic drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Dr. Harry Lever, a cardiologist at the Cleveland Clinic, has been warning nearly anyone who would listen of his growing suspicions about generic versions of a widely used heart drug, Toprol XL.

articles.headline: Neil Barofsky, Old Foe of Bank Bailouts, Said to Be a Monitor for Credit Suisse
articles.snippet: Neil Barofsky was a government gadfly who made a career of needling, and at times pillorying, Wall Street and Washington over the 2008 bank bailouts.
articles.abstract: Neil Barofsky was a government gadfly who made a career of needling, and at times pillorying, Wall Street and Washington over the 2008 bank bailouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Neil Barofsky was a government gadfly who made a career of needling, and at times pillorying, Wall Street and Washington over the 2008 bank bailouts.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Realizing the American Apparel Chief, Dov Charney, Isn’t Wearing Any Clothes
articles.snippet: Dov Charney’s dismissal raises all sorts of thorny corporate-governance questions for investors and boards about iconic — and notorious — leaders, especially in creative fields.
articles.abstract: Dov Charney’s dismissal raises all sorts of thorny corporate-governance questions for investors and boards about iconic — and notorious — leaders, especially in creative fields.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dov Charney is completely naked. He is dancing in what looks like an office or studio, talking on his cellphone while he jams to “This Must Be the Place” by Talking Heads. Two women are there with him, possibly employees.

articles.headline: In Time Warp of Soccer, It Ain’t Over Till ... Who Knows?
articles.snippet: With the stoppage time rule, soccer, a timed game, actually ends only when the referee decides it has ended.
articles.abstract: With the stoppage time rule, soccer, a timed game, actually ends only when the referee decides it has ended.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAUS, Brazil — Imagine if an N.F.L. coach never knew when to call for the last-second pass, or an N.B.A. star had to guess when to throw up his desperation half-court shot.

articles.headline: For Women in Midlife, Career Gains Slip Away
articles.snippet: Many women are leaving the work force in their peak earning years, a setback for the economy that also bucks a powerful decades-long movement.
articles.abstract: Many women are leaving the work force in their peak earning years, a setback for the economy that also bucks a powerful decades-long movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tracy Murphy was managing a nonprofit agency five years ago when her mother became seriously ill with heart problems. She promptly left her job to care for her, a task that has consumed Ms. Murphy ever since.

articles.headline: Ex-Tabloid Executive Acquitted in British Phone Hacking Case
articles.snippet: Rebekah Brooks, the former head of Rupert Murdoch’s newspaper holdings in Britain, was cleared of all charges, but her onetime deputy Andy Coulson was found guilty on at least one count.
articles.abstract: Rebekah Brooks, the former head of Rupert Murdoch’s newspaper holdings in Britain, was cleared of all charges, but her onetime deputy Andy Coulson was found guilty on at least one count.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — She rose from being a secretary in Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper empire to running it. She called prime ministers her friends. Then she found herself in the middle of one of the most riveting trials in years, accused of illegally intercepting voice mails and other crimes, alongside her husband and her former deputy, who it turned out, was also her lover.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Alan Cowell

articles.headline: Cochran Holds Off Tea Party Challenger in Mississippi
articles.snippet: A surge of voters showed up on Tuesday in African-American precincts and delivered Senator Thad Cochran a hard-fought victory over his Tea Party challenger, Chris McDaniel.
articles.abstract: A surge of voters showed up on Tuesday in African-American precincts and delivered Senator Thad Cochran a hard-fought victory over his Tea Party challenger, Chris McDaniel.
articles.lead_paragraph: HATTIESBURG, Miss. — With an unusual assist from African-American voters and other Democrats who feared his opponent, Senator Thad Cochran on Tuesday beat back a spirited challenge from State Senator Chris McDaniel, triumphing in a Republican runoff and defeating the Tea Party in the state where the movement’s hopes were bright.
